An unknown (sic!) disease rages at Turbat-l-Sheikh Jam. Three to four deaths aday. Governor demands help. Plague In tho Kermanshah district . The following Is a resume of the reports received from the Governor since the last meeting of the Council (June 5th). June 15th . The epidemic exists in the Kalhor district and at Liah-l-Dasht. A commission has boon formed at Kemanshah to carry out the necessary measures. A Persian doctor with 50 Cossacks has left for the affected district. June. 17th . Ifeh-i-Dasht; no deaths for 13 days. jam-i-Shuran; no deaths for 7 days. Zanireh; no deaths for 6 days. June 22nd . Harunabad; one death on the 20th. The inhabitants have scattered and carried the disease to Suran-Larz, Nokneh, Lenjai, Karend and Surkheh Dlseh. June 50th . Jam-i-Shuran; one case daily. In each telegram the Governor urged that doctors ho sont from Tehran. As Dr.Heydar liilrza who was selected for plague duty by the Council at its meeting onon June 5th was present at this meeting, I asked why he had not left Tehran,, Dr.Gachet in reply said that in order to give ef fect to the measures which the Council had proposed to take with regard to the epidemics In Khorassan and in Kermanshah, he had limed lately infomied the Governor of them. In the case of Khorassan he had submitted to them the telegram from the Russian doctor at Kariz which askod for 10,000 tomans limed lately (see proces verbal of meeting of June 5th page 168). In the case of Ker manshah he had asked for pay and travelling expenses for the doctors chosen by the Council for plague duty. The Minister of the Interior had replied that the Council had 15,000 tomans a year secured on the northern customs and that it should use this money for dealing with the present epidemics. Dr.Gachet had replied that this money* was intended purely for the sanitary service in the Caspian Sea, and that he could not agree to its being spent on other objects. He had pressed the Government but had been met with a refusal to grant the Council any money while it had any of the 15,000 tomans to its credit. Dr. Neligan to Sir W. Townley. ^' ir > ^ Tehran, March 4, 1913. I HA\ E the honour to report that a meeting of the Sanitary Council was held to-day—Hr. Gachet, the President, in the chair. Telegrams were read from the Governor and from the delegate of the Sanitary Council at Kermanshah, which described an epidemic of an acute and very fatal disease in the neighbourhood of Khoramabad. It had begun apparently in October, and had lasted three and a-half months. In one village sixty out of one hundred people attacked had died. The symptoms were “swelling of the glands in the neck, axilla and groin, with fever and constipation.” The delegate had seen only two cases, one dead, the other recovered. He gave it as his opinion that the disease was anthrax. The villagers said it was due to eating the flesh of some sheep that had died. Several members at once stated their opinion that, in view of the symptoms described, the epidemic could be nothing less than plague. The Turkish delegate then read a note in which he took the same view, adduced the authority of Pronst and Tholozan as to previous epidemics in the same region, and stated his opinion that the recent epidemic of plague in Khorasan was started by the movement of nomads to that province from Kermanshah. He furthur criticised the responsible authorities for not having taken action, and asked what was to be done. After a good deal of rather excited discussion 1 said that, contrary to what had been said, I knew of several out breaks of anthrax in country villages in Persia ; that it was inconceivable that plague could be carried from the Turkish frontier to the Afghan frontier by nomads, in view of the fact that they did not migrate so far; that though the symptoms described suggested plague very strongly, the council could not do more than express this opinion, ask for further information and be prepared to take immediate action should there be another outbreak in the future, in order to settle the diagnosis. These views were approved of, and it was decided to ask the Government to arrange for an enquiry sur place by the liussian doctor at Kermanshah, the Turkish sanitary delegate who is to arrive there shortly, and the local Persian doctors. The proces-verhal of the last and final meeting of the Sanitary Commission at Meshed was read. At it the report of Captain Wilson and Hr. i'aplotinsky had been approved, and the nature of the epidemic—namely plague—reaffirmed. The removal of the quarantine cordon was also approved. Several liussian doctors, Captain Wilson and two Russian officers were recommended for decorations. A procif^verbal of a meeting at Karez, which was assembled when Captain Wilson and Hr. Zaplotinsky arrived there in the course of their investigation was also read. EASTERN SANITARY REEORMS. CON EIHENTIAL. Section 2. [12981] No. 1. Sir JV. My dear Baron Muller, Vienna, January 30, 1912. •R I P-N l UPLE to trouble you with a small matter, which, however, interests the British Government, but as I do not wish to take it up officially I make an appeal to your good offices in my private capacity. The matter relates to the excess of zeal shown by Dr. Feistmantel, the Austro-Hungarian representative on the Tehran oanitary Council, who seems to be inclined to raise questions which go beyond his proper province, and which in the present unsettled state of things in Persia had perhaps better be left untouched. ° I enclose an aide-memoire with further details explaining what His Maiestys Government complain of. As Dr. Feistmantel is, I am told, at present on leave in this country, an opportunity may perhaps present itself when vou might see proper to advise him to be a little more discreet and cautious in his attitude. Yours very truly, FAIRFAX L. CARTWRIGHT. Enclosure 2 in No. 1 . Aide-memoire. (Private and Confidential.) IT has been brought to the notice of His Britannic Majesty’s Government that an unsatisfactory situation has been created in the affairs of the Persian Gulf sanitary service by the misdirected zeal of Dr. Feistmantel, the Austro-Hungarian delegate on he Tehran Sanitary Council, and by his attitude towards the Gulf quarantine adminis- ration, which is under British management and composed of officers of the Indian Medical Service. It appears that Dr. Feistmantel has for some years past been very active in his criticisms and even attacks on that administration, and to have caused some difficulty by unnecessarily raising the question of the sanitary defence of the Persian Gulf. In particular, at a meeting of the Tehran Sanitary Council on the 30th April, f910, Dr. Feistmantel appears to have read an attack on the chief quarantine officer 111 r eference to the epidemic of plague which had broken out at Bushire. He endeavoured to show that this officer had been lacking in his duty in not orderinn ] ‘5 JUL1912* [2528 e —1] 27 llTP I i2 sanitary measures against persons leaving Bahrein ; whereas, as a matter of fact, there was at the time no plague in the island, and, moreover, Bahrein is outside the sphere of the quarantine service. Dr. Feistmantel also prepared a scheme for imposing- quarantine dues on shipping in the Gulf. Again at a meeting on the 1st May, 1911' Dr. Beistmantel read a note on the plague epidemics in the Gulf, and added that, as acting Turkish delegate, he would draw the attention of the Constantinople Board of Health to the question. This note appears to have been based on inaccurate and outside information, whereas a report on the epidemic had already been received by the Sanitary Council from the chief quarantine officer. On the 28th August Dr. Deist mantel made a formal proposal to invite a commission of the Constantinople Board of Health to visit the Gulf and study the sanitary situation there. While the British authorities do not, of course, object to any fair criticism of the Gulf quarantine service, they feel that the proposals of Dr. Feistmantel, apart from the inadvisability of opening the whole question of the sanitary defence of the Gulf, including sentinel stations under international control, are likely to cause entirely | unnecessary trouble, besides encroaching on matters in which the Persian Government is primarily concerned. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the volume.The subject 2410 (Tehran Sanitary Council) consists of 2 volumes, IOR/L/PS/10/283-284. The volumes are divided into 2 parts, with each part comprising one volume.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the inside front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 208; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The volume contains part 1 of papers from and about the Tehran Sanitary Council (also referred to as the Conseil Sanitaire de l’Empire de Perse). It chiefly comprises copies of the proceedings (in French) of the 99 through to the 127 meetings of the Council, forwarded by the British Ambassador at Tehran (Sir George Head Barclay; Sir Walter Beaupre Townley) to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (Sir Edward Grey), and then forwarded by the Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, to the Under-Secretary of State for India.The proceedings detail reports of epidemics (including plague, cholera, malaria) occurring in Persia and its neighbours (including the Persian Gulf, Russia, India), and measures taken to implement quarantine and vaccination measures to prevent their spread. In the reports, recurring mention is made of epidemics in Kermanshah [Kermānshāh], Khorassan [Khorāsān], Bouchir [Bushire] and Astrakhan. Interspersed with the meeting proceedings are copies of British Government correspondence, chiefly in the form of detailed accounts of the meetings, written by Dr Anthony Richard Neligan, physician at the British Legation in Tehran, who attended meetings in his capacity as Doctor of the Legation (Médecins de Légations).The part includes a divider which gives the subject and part number, the year the subject file was opened, the subject heading, and a list of correspondence references contained in that part by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence (f 3).
